remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Hello, thank you for coming in today. I understand you’ve been experiencing shortness of breath and persistent nausea. Can you describe when these symptoms began and if there’s anything that assessms to make them better or worse?

Hi, um… yeah, I’ve been having a lot of shortness of breath lately. It’s kind of hard to say exactly when it started, but it’s been getting worse over the past few days. I’m just… I’m pretty anxious about it.

I can understand why you’re experiencing anxious—shortness of breath can be very unsettling. In addition to your breathing symptoms, have you also been experiencing persistent nausea or vomiting recently?
Yeah, um… I have been feeling pretty nauseous, and I’ve thrown up a couple times. I also have some pain, but I’m not sure if it’s related. I just… I don’t feel right at all.

Thank you for sharing how you’re experiencing—it’s important we understand all your symptoms. You mentioned pain along with your nausea and vomiting; can you tell me where the pain is located and how severe it has been?

remedi_labels.value: Thank you for sharing how you’re experiencing—it’s important we understand all your symptoms.

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Well, um… the pain is mostly in my chest. It’s not super sharp, but it’s kind of a pressure, and sometimes it gets worse when I’m breathing in. The nausea is pretty constant, and I just feel really uncomfortable. I’m honestly a bit worried about the chest pain—should I be concerned?

I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially with both chest discomfort and persistent nausea. To help with my assessment, can you tell me if your vomiting has included any blood or if you’ve noticed any changes in the color or amount of what you bring up?

remedi_labels.value: changes in color or amount of vomit

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Um… no, I haven’t seen any blood in my vomit. It’s mostly just been kind of clear or yellowish, I think. I haven’t really noticed a big change in the amount, but it’s just that the nausea doesn’t really go away. I’m still feeling pretty anxious about all these symptoms.

I can understand why you’d be worried about these ongoing symptoms, especially with persistent nausea and chest discomfort. Given your recent clinical assessment showed bilateral pleural effusions, have you noticed any swelling in your legs or difficulty lying flat due to shortness of breath?

remedi_labels.value: difficulty lying flat due to shortness of breath

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: Yeah, actually… now that you mention it, I have noticed some swelling in my legs. It’s been getting worse, especially around my ankles. And, um, it’s definitely harder for me to lie flat—I get more shortness of breath when I try. I remember the doctor mentioning something about bilateral pleural effusions and bilateral opacities, right greater than left, on my last scan. I guess that’s related to the air space disease? It’s just making me more anxious because I’m not sure what all that means for my breathing.

remedi_labels.value: shortness of breath when lying flat
bilateral opacities, right greater than left

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be anxious, especially with new findings on your imaging and ongoing symptoms. Given the bilateral opacities and air space disease noted on your recent assessment, have you experienced any cough, sputum production, or fevers that might suggest an underlying infection or worsening pulmonary condition?

remedi_labels.value: bilateral opacities and air space disease

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Yeah, actually… I have had a bit of a cough, but it’s not really productive—there’s not much sputum. I did have some fevers off and on, but I wasn’t sure if that was related. And, um, I remember someone mentioning worsening pulmonary edema on my last assessment. I’m not sure if that’s what’s making my breathing worse, but it feels like it’s getting harder to catch my breath.

Also, I’ve noticed it’s been taking me longer to swallow—like, slow oral transit? Sometimes I feel like symptoms just kind of sit in my throat for a while before going down. Is that something I should be worried about with all these other symptoms?

remedi_labels.value: Should I be worried about these symptoms together?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about these symptoms, especially with the combination of persistent vomiting, difficulty swallowing, and findings of bilateral opacities on your recent assessment. To help clarify the underlying condition, have you noticed any changes in your voice, episodes of choking, or coughing while eating or drinking that might suggest aspiration or worsening swallowing difficulties?

Yeah, um… actually, I have noticed some changes with my swallowing. Sometimes when I drink thin liquids, especially if it’s mixed with something else, I feel like it kind of goes down the wrong way. I think the speech therapist mentioned something about mild penetration of thin consistencies into the laryngeal vestibule, and maybe even probable trace aspiration of thin liquid—but only when it was a mixed consistency. I do cough sometimes when that happens, but not every time. My voice hasn’t really changed much, but I am worried about this whole aspiration thing. Is that something that could make my breathing or my other symptoms worse?

remedi_labels.value: possible mild penetration of thin consistencies into laryngeal vestibule
probable trace aspiration of thin liquid with mixed consistency
Could aspiration make breathing or other symptoms worse?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried about the possibility of aspiration, especially with your recent symptoms and the findings from your swallowing assessment. Given your history of vomiting and the bilateral opacities assessn on your imaging, have you noticed any recent worsening of your cough, increased shortness of breath, or new fevers that could suggest aspiration pneumonia or a respiratory infection?

Yeah, um… my shortness of breath has definitely gotten worse lately, and I feel like I get winded a lot faster than before. The cough is still there, but it hasn’t really changed much—it’s just kind of dry, not really bringing anything up. I did have some fevers a couple days ago, but they seem to come and go.

Actually, I wanted to ask about something else too. I noticed on my labs that my glucose levels have been kind of all over the place—sometimes high, sometimes even low, which is unusual for me. And my urea nitrogen has been bouncing around too—sometimes it’s elevated, sometimes it drops. Is that something I should be worried about with everything else going on? I just feel like there’s a lot happening at once, and I’m not sure what’s most important to focus on right now.

remedi_labels.value: shortness of breath has gotten worse
glucose levels sometimes high, sometimes low
Should I be worried about these lab results?
What should I focus on right now?

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text: I can understand why you’d be worried, especially with so many symptoms and lab fluctuations happening at once. Based on your recent clinical assessment—including persistent vomiting, bilateral pulmonary opacities consistent with air space disease, and variable glucose and urea nitrogen levels—it’s important to evaluate for ongoing metabolic disturbances or possible infection. Have you noticed any changes in your mental status, such as increased confusion, drowsiness, or difficulty concentrating, that might suggest worsening metabolic encephalopathy or infection?

remedi_labels.value: variable glucose and urea nitrogen levels
changes in mental status (increased confusion, drowsiness, difficulty concentrating)

remedi_style_dialogue_annotations.utterance_text:
Yeah, actually… now that you mention it, I have been feeling a lot more drowsy and kind of slow lately. Sometimes it’s hard to concentrate, and I just feel out of it—almost like my brain is foggy. My family said I seemed less responsive a couple times, and I’ve noticed I’m moving slower, especially on my left side. It’s honestly a little scary.

I also saw on my labs that my creatinine has been mildly elevated at times, and there have been some electrolyte abnormalities—like my sodium, potassium, chloride, and bicarbonate have all been fluctuating. The anion gap has been off too. I’m just worried that all these metabolic disturbances are adding up and making symptoms worse. Should I be really concerned about these changes? Is this something that could get better, or is it a sign that symptoms are getting more serious?

I also saw in my labs that my ferritin and TIBC are off—someone mentioned it could be an iron metabolism disorder?
